Tbree little girls, eqed 4 to 7. pictured ir» pU y toq» et lower right, would be fatherless orphans today had eet their father, Gorden Perimer», W alworth county farmer, been brought back to cofisciousneis by Arthur M . La k e g e n e v a , w is . — Gold m edals o f Employers Mutual^ of W au sau were awarded Dec. 15 to Arthur M. Andresen and Peter Koenen, Lake Geneva, linemen for the Wisconsin Power and Light C om pany, for saving two lives by the Schaefer prone pressure method of resuscitation. Andresen also received thfc bronze medal of the National Safety council. Taking a short cut on country road to reach De lavan during g severe electric storm May 28, Andresen and Sidney Rouse, foreman of the line crew, were halted by George Amann, Elkhom implement dealer, and James Reedy, Deiavan, employed by Amann. They called ittention of the power company men to Periman lying under an oak tree where he had sought shelter from the storm. Penman’s team had run •.w ay; his dog lay dead near him. Rouse hastened to Deiavan and returned with Dr. James W. Doughty. Meantime Andresen had wormed Penman’s inert b o d y ; the lightning victim stirred and struggled to rise just as the physician arrived. A few minutes later he was safely home with wife and children; t next day he worked as usual. Koenen, a groundmsn, saved the life of Fred Moldenhauer, a Lake Geneva lineman, when he fell with a pole in an accident at Darien on Sept. 16,1937. Sustaining a serious head injury when he fell, Moldenhauer went into a stupor, with natural breathing halted. Beginning immediately after the fall and continuing during the ambulance ride to the Beleit hospital, more than an hour in all, Koenen worked over the injured i g g g artificial ration by tie J%r method. Physicians declared that but for this effort by Koenen, the injured man would have died from suffocation long before airiving at the hospital. Scent Guides Lives of S Creatures of the Wild The power of §eent plays a vital p a rt in the lives of all creatu res of the wild. Through it they receive advance notice, by way of the air currents, of the presence of enem ies. a re able to recognize their kind and And m ates. In fact, alm ost every m om ent of th eir existence is influenced by the sense of sm ell, and the distance over which they are able to pick up a scent is truly astonishing. Thus to the weak- !er fratern ity the air often c arrie s terrorizing new3, while to the strong it w afts a gratifying m essage of a m eal in prospect, according to Mack B. Stielau. se cre ta ry D etroit Izaak Walton league, in the D etroit News. The very young of m ost species do not em it a scent, but w hether this is due to im m aturity, or a wise provision of n atu re to protect her helpless children, we do not know. All kindred of the wild, however, instinctively recognize the scent of their n atu ral enem ies, and either hide or hasten to get as far aw ay from it as possible. E ven while at play, tim e is taken out by the young to sniff the a ir for alien odors. Tins sam e tra it m ay also be observed by som e dom estic anim als. In the Insect world, sm ell also plays an im p o sa n t p a rt and we find th at the eentinel bees are able to delect and keep ‘‘foreign” kin from entering the hive It guides the butterfly and the m oth to the fem ale, and it is said th a t in the pursuit they a re able to discover the last spot on which she rested. Through this sense the lowly ticks which attach them selves to some anim als a « able to pick a suitable host on vTuich to satisfy th eir unquenchable th irst for blood. Daring adventure of ra n . untamed frontier Old Viking P ort of Bergen Situated at the head cf the Bergensfjord and pierced by its three branches, the old Viking port of Bergen. Norway, lies wedged in between its quays and its m ountains, w ith Floifjellet, over 1.000 feet high, rising a t its back door. Tile-roofed houses in white and yellow stick to the m ountain's sheer slopes like pins on a m ap, and a cable-car takes trav elers up to Floien on its crest, w’here they can look down on the city and the fjord spread out below. On the old G erm an quay is Nordnes, the oldest p art of the city, where tiny houses, jam m ed one against another, clm g precariously to the slopes of a steep hill and n a rrow streets clim b s zig zag course to the tcp These houses are ancient, and Bergen, in spite of its jum ble of ¿raffle, the life and color cf its fish m ark et, is an ancient city. Dallas, T e x si —Two A m ericans with a m utual desire for speed aboard a sled, originated, so the record book reveals, m ountain tob o g # ming. The tim e was back In i 8Ô0 and the place was St. Moritz, in the Swiss Alps. But a quarter^century before th at tim e, between 18à0 and 1870 hardy M exican m iners scooted àown the steep, snow-covered slopes of the volcanic m ountain, Popocatepetl, using huge sacks of sulphur ore for toboggans, combini ‘3 business with pleasure. The two A m ericans, known in the record book only as “ Mr. Wilson and Mr. Smith,’ went into tobogganing for the thrill gt the sport. The Mexicans, no nnm es known, w ent into tobogganing as a of transportation. Donald B. Mason, chem ical engineer of the F re ep o rt Sulphur company, brought the story to light here in a review of the world sulphur industry before m em bers of the A m erican Chem ical society. Coes Rack to Corte. Ris story went back to 1519 when H ernando Cortez. Spanish conquer or of Mexico, sent an exploration p arty to the sum m it of Mount Popocatepetl. which a t th at time was in •n unusual sta te of volcanic activity. Shortly afterw ards Cortez found him self cut off from his arm am ent supplies, chiefly gunpowder. C arbon eotVJ be obtained from ch arcoal. i ( ^ e t e r could be taken from nearby caves. Wfth a supply of sulphur the exoedition codld m ake Its own gunpowder. So a w of the h ardiest descended 500 feet into the c ra te r of the m ountain, bringing out enough sulphur ore for 50 casks of powder. The Cortez exploit represented the Initial production ot sulphur in the w estern hem isphere It w asn't un ti| i85Q th a t attem p ts were m ade to utilize com m ercially the sulphur ore to be found deep in Mount Popocatepetl. At various tim es, over a period of 10 or 15 years, sulphur w as taken from the c rater bv m eans of w indlasses m ounted on top of the wall. Rope baskets w ere let down Carrying m iners who filled sacks with ore and w ere then hoisted back to the top. P a rt of the transportation from the top of the c ratcr down to the refinery was carried out by the m iners using the bags of ore as •ieds for a 3.000 foot section of the 17,000 foot journey. From the bottom of the toboggan run tran sp o rtation was m aintained to the base of the m ountain on hum an shoulders. The two problem s of transporting the sulphur from the c rater to the rim and from the rim to the re finery have alw ays balked com m ercial developm ent of the deposit. While the Cortea venture in sulphur “m ining” took place m ore than 400 years ago. it was not until 1903. when the “ hot water' method of m elting the sulphur underground and m ining it from guif coast salt dom es was introduced, that com m ercial m inthg of sulphur becam e successful on this side of the Atlantic ocean, Texas and Louisiana salt domes now accouht for nearly • third ot the world production of sulphur from all sources. She m ade several trial, but in vain, sa y s th e M o n treal H erald, th en gave up in d isg u st, and, tu rn in g to th e m an behind th e grilled w indow tried freeze him w ith a g la re a s4 ju re m a n d e d : “ Is th is tn e pen K ing Jo h n u sed w hen sig n in g M agna C h a rt» ” T he official replied: “In fo rm i tion a t the n e x t window, please.” About tne Sw astika The sw astika, oldest of all A ryan sym bols, is definitely pre-C hristian and m any specim ens of it have been found in the diggings of old Troy. F rom its rough likeness to a wheel it is associated by som e with the solar motion and early w orship of the sun. though the, m ost im portan t of its attributes, in ancient usage, is its c h a ra c te r as a charm , a sign of benediction, of long life and good luck. It is the sacred symbol of one Buddhist sect, and from tim e im m em orial has been to all peoples of Asia. The fact th at it w as not unknown to the A m erican Indian is held to point to early com m unication betw een the hem ispheres. The word, sw astika, says the D etroit News, derives from the Sanskrit “ su” m eaning well, and "isti” which m eans being. On the bust of Apollo m V ienna’s fam ed m useum of historical a r t is a large and unm istakable sw astika, which b ears out the supposed so lar significance, and identifies th at god, p e rhaps, as the fir'st of the A ustrian Nazis. L uella an d Ja c k ie H abeim an S m a l l T a b l e s f o r H o m e s U s e d in A n c ie n t T im ^ s In Quoen E lizabeth s tim e, tables for the m ost p a rt w ere of the board and hingedboard type supported on trestles. The E lizabethans had little need for sm all tables in th eir m ode of living, but with the developm ent of printing, the reading of books a t night required a read ju stm ent of lighting and ihe sm all table was the result We can tra c e through these sm all pieces of furnitu re the influence of the age of Queen Anne, the early Georges, tne various French Louis periods and oa through the em pire, w rites an authority in the Los Angeles Tim es. Tne sm all table as a d istin rt Article of furniture cam e into popularity in England about the m iddle of the E ighteenth century when the gene ral use of tea. coffee and cfeocciate required furniture «if this type We find a t this tim e the dropleaf, octagonal, gateleg, trian g u lar dropleaf and tripod base, tile-top, tiny candlestands, butterfly, lyre-m otif and a g reat num ber of other form s. of them were designed with plain or cabriole legs, having spade or claw-and-ball feet, plain or carv ed knees We can safely say thr general type w as the tripod.
